image.altText: A Holden ute lifted into the air by a crane

items.synopsis: The Holden ute, worth an estimated $20,000, was reduced to scrap metal by police today, about six months after it was clocked at "one of the highest ever speeds" detected on South Australian roads.

title.children: Holden ute previously clocked at 253kph on Adelaide motorway crushed by police

image.altText: Daniel Troy Ames has been jailed for apparent execution style murder of his uncle

items.synopsis: Convicted killer Daniel Troy Ames, who was jailed for the 2009 execution-style murder of his uncle, loses a legal bid to secure a retrial, with an Adelaide court dismissing claims of a deathbed confession by a drug dealer as neither "reliable" nor "compelling".

title.children: Uncle killer loses appeal after court rejects claims of drug dealer 'deathbed confession'

image.altText: Several boats are moored at a marina, with palm trees in the background and a shed on the shore

items.synopsis: When two boats set off towards an Indonesian island for a birthday surfing trip, none of those on board could have predicted the next few days. Here's how the survivors managed more than 36 hours at sea.

title.children: How a split-second decision may have saved four Australians

image.altText: A woman looks into the camera and smiles slightly.

items.synopsis: It's legal for one law firm to represent both sides of a real estate transaction but legal experts warn it can make navigating conflict difficult.

title.children: When Christine sold her home, the buyer used the same law firm. Things soon became 'very sticky'

image.altText: Rear shot of a woman in a purple coat holding a grey mug

items.synopsis: More than 170,000 people across Australia are on the housing waitlist, including people like Annabelle, who faces living out of a car with her cat in a few weeks.

title.children: Annabelle is uni-educated and has an impressive corporate background. She's also homeless at the age of 54

image.altText: A man wearing glasses and a suit stands behind a lectern labelled "Working for Australia".

items.synopsis: Prime Minister Anthony Albanese faces off against an internal rebellion on AUKUS, as some delegates attempt to have references to nuclear-powered submarines struck from the party's platform.

title.children: Albanese defends against attempt to strike nuclear submarines out of Labor platform

image.altText: Alisha Fagan appears serious as she stands outside a court building in Melbourne.

items.synopsis: Alisha Fagan, who caused the death of 69-year-old grandfather Sedat Hassan in a 2022 crash, will be eligible for parole in less than six months.

title.children: Melbourne driver who killed grandfather then blamed crash on 'African men' jailed

image.altText: John Devitt

items.synopsis: Australian swimming is mourning the death of Olympic gold medallist John Devitt, who broke 14 world records across his 13-year swimming career.

title.children: Aussie swimmer who broke 14 world records and won two Olympic gold medals dies aged 86

image.altText: A court build with a columned verandah and a blue coloured building behind

items.synopsis: Mohammed Abdi Abdulahi faces the Adelaide Magistrates Court after being extradited from Victoria by detectives from the Special Crimes Investigation Section, and did not apply for bail.

title.children: Fifth man faces court over alleged rape in Adelaide's west

image.altText: A soccer player wearing yellow and green sits on her haunches after a game

items.synopsis: Mystery surrounded Alanna Kennedy's late withdrawal from Australia's clash with England, but the Matildas have since confirmed the defender has delayed concussion symptoms.

title.children: Matildas defender Alanna Kennedy to miss Sweden match as reason for semifinal absence is confirmed

image.altText: A pictographic showing 147 icons of stadiums

items.synopsis: More than 11 million Australians watched the Matildas take on England in the FIFA World Cup semifinal in a new national record — here's how that number stacks up.

title.children: How many stadiums could stay-at-home Matildas fans have packed into?

image.altText: A man and a woman standing outside a modern-looking pub

items.synopsis: Two famous country pubs near Mount Gambier are set to reopen ahead of summer, with both new operators planning to remove the venues' poker machines to make them more family-friendly.

title.children: Why these South Australians want to give pubs without pokies a 'red hot go' in favour of families

image.altText: A man smiling with the ocean and red sand behind him.

items.synopsis: Roger Cook says the government's position strikes the right balance between development, environmental protection, and landowner rights, but Kimberley campaign groups say the fight for a complete ban will continue.

title.children: WA premier says fracking policies won't change as environmental groups push for Kimberley ban

image.altText: A representation of virtual currency Bitcoin and US banknotes.

items.synopsis: Bitcoin's value dropped by as much as 9 per cent after a report about SpaceX's finances, while China's second-largest property developer has filed for Chapter 15 bankruptcy protection. Follow live.

title.children: Bitcoin plummets after SpaceX report, China's Evergrande files for bankruptcy protection in US, ASX picks up

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: After seven weeks of gains, oil prices look set to bring that winning streak to an end come Friday. The reason? There's brewing concerns about demand growth in China as its economy slows, coupled with fears about US rates staying higher for longe r. Both the major benchmarks for West Texas Intermediate crude and B rent crude are fairly flat, with the US Federal Reserve's focus on containing inflation alongside stronger-than-expected economic data keeping the prices mostly contained. Reuters reports that investors are concerned that should the Fed leave rates higher for longer, those higher borrowing costs could stifle economic growth, and reduce overall demand — including for oil. On top of the US concerns, China's sputtering economy has added to contagion fears, which has only added to oil concerns, as it's the world's second-largest oil consumer. Back in July, China made a very rare draw on its crude oil inventories, which was the first time in 33 months it dipped into its storage, while US crude oil inventories fell by almost 6 million barrels last week.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: Oil prices set to snap winning streak as Chinese economy slows

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: The ASX has turned a corner and picked up some positive gains as we approach 1pm AEST — it's sitting around 0.2% higher at 7,162 points. The reason? Real estate stocks are having a blinder right now — the sector is up 2.4% and leaving the other sectors in the dust. Utilities have gained 1.4%, while basic materials are up 1.1% and academics are 0.4% higher. At the other end, technology is down 1%, while consumer cyclicals are down 0.9% and industrials has shed 0.5%. As for the top movers, it's Magellan Financial's day in the sun: Magellan Financial +19.7% Abacus Property +11.6% Goodman Group +7.9% Inghams +5.5% Core Lithium +5.5% Meanwhile at the other end of the scale: Imugene -13.3% Domain -6.7% Centuria Capital -5.3% Super Retail Group -5.1% Growthpoint Properties -3.9%
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: ASX makes up some ground, all thanks to real estate

liveBlogPostPrepared.plaintext: It might feel like we've had plenty of big companies report their earnings for the past financial year (which is undoubtedly true) — but there is plenty more on the way in the next couple of weeks. If you need to update your calendar (or want to check whether a certain company has reported), here's a searchable table I prepared earlier.
liveBlogPostPrepared.title: We're only halfway through reporting season — here's who else is yet to post their earnings

children.content: It might feel like we've had plenty of big companies report their earnings for the past financial year (which is undoubtedly true) — but there is plenty more on the way in the next couple of weeks.
If you need to update your calendar (or want to check whether a certain company has reported), here's a searchable table I prepared earlier.

image.altText: Naotunne Vijitha, dressed in an overcoat and yellow beanie, walks outside a court building in Melbourne.

items.synopsis: The Venerable Naotunne Vijitha Nayaka Thero, who is the abbot of the Dhamma Sarana temple in Melbourne's south-east, is facing 13 charges including sexual penetration of a child under 16 and indecent act with a child under 16.

title.children: Buddhist monk at Melbourne temple faces court on child sex abuse charges

image.altText: A close-up shot of large plastic-wrapped packages containing cocaine and taped up with Australian Federal Police tape.

items.synopsis: Three Queensland men are charged with importing 560 kilograms of cocaine into Western Australia, with the group allegedly collecting the drugs off the coast after they were dropped off by a bulk carrier.

title.children: Police seize half a tonne of cocaine from house after trio allegedly smuggled drugs in via boat

image.altText: A selfie of a young man wearing a hat

items.synopsis: Police say a man and a woman were inside RQ's Tavern at Robina for about 90 seconds before a 26-year-old man was allegedly stabbed in the chest.

title.children: Man, 26, allegedly killed within 90 seconds of couple entering Gold Coast pub, police say

image.altText: A college of a magpie, fairywren and cicada against a blue sky backdrop complete with green grass.

items.synopsis: After hundreds of thousands of votes, the magpie has been crowned Australia's favourite animal sound, beating out the kookaburra and butcherbird to snatch the title.

title.children: Magpie swoops in and claims title of Australia's favourite animal sound in landslide win

image.altText: Profile photos of two young men.

items.synopsis: Two men, including the brother of NRL star Payne Haas, have been refused bail for a second time after facing a NSW court accused of trafficking a commercial quantity of methylamphetamine.

title.children: Zeda Haas and Kaharua Beer refused bail over alleged role in $3.5m meth importation

image.altText: Roof tops of houses

items.synopsis: Labor has reactivated its Help to Buy scheme, which means you can move into a "home" with just a 2 per cent deposit.

title.children: The federal government will offer some people the chance to buy a home with a 2pc deposit. Here's how it works

image.altText: A group of men sit solemnly on chairs lined up at the service, some in uniform and wearing medals

items.synopsis: Crowds gather to mark 50 years since troops were withdrawn from the Vietnam War, the longest 20th-century conflict in which Australians participated.

title.children: Australian troops left Vietnam 50 years ago, but for many the pain would continue once they arrived home

image.altText: A person holding a Rapid Antigen Test on a blue desk

items.synopsis: Here's a quick wrap of the COVID-19 news and case numbers from each Australian jurisdiction from the past week.

title.children: All the latest COVID-19 case numbers from around Australia — plus the news you may have missed

image.altText: A man pointing a weapon.

items.synopsis: Barry Vassella's anxiety emerged with the sudden force of a gunshot, overwhelmed by a memory he could not yet decipher, and sparked simply by a log on the ground at a golf course.

title.children: Our Vietnam War was more than the hundreds killed — the aftermath was confronting for the 60,000 who served

image.altText: A man and a woman hug, and laugh

items.synopsis: Even when things didn't go to plan, Sir Michael Parkinson's subjects seemed to make great television — here are some of the most memorable moments from the legendary interviewer's chats.

title.children: Five of Parky's most memorable interviews: From John and Yoko to Meg Ryan and Dame Edna

image.altText: Michael Parkinson

items.synopsis: It's hard to believe there was anyone Sir Michael Parkinson hadn't spoken to during his glittering decades-long media career — but last year, he said there was one more interview he'd like to do.

title.children: 'We're in the palm of his hand': The man Michael Parkinson wanted to interview last year

image.altText: A map of Australia with multiple curving orange lines crossing it in different directions.

items.synopsis: Hundreds of Chinese satellites are currently passing over Australia collecting intelligence on military training activities involving the United States and other regional partners, according to commercial space data obtained by the ABC.

title.children: China deploys swarm of satellites to monitor military exercises in Australia

image.altText: Warren Mundine in the main street of Nowra

items.synopsis: Quotes and audio have been circulating online purporting to show that No campaigner Warren Mundine formerly supported the Voice but has changed his position. Is that correct?

title.children: Did Warren Mundine change his tune on the Voice? Here's what he has said

image.altText: a handful of free-range eggs

items.synopsis: The suspected mushroom-poisoning deaths in Victoria of three people following a lunch has put a focus on the potential consequences of eating the wrong thing. Here's what food safety experts want you to know about food poisoning.

title.children: Here's what a microbiologist says you should know about food poisoning

image.altText: Brunette mother holds two toddlers and a baby.

items.synopsis: With limited affordable options available, pregnant Courtney Louise and her young family found themselves stuck in a mould-infested house for five long months, seeking help from her real estate provider in vain.

title.children: Young mother of three forced to hound real estate agent for months to fix mould, fruit fly infestation

image.altText: older bearded man holding coffee standing on verandah with ocean behind

items.synopsis: Allan "Clarkie" Clarke's 32-year tenure on prime Sunshine Coast land will end when the property's new owner gets started on a luxury unit complex.

title.children: Clarkie's paradise lost as developer snaps up last beachfront shack

image.altText: A grinning man smiles as he looks down at his smiling bride, with her white veil pulled back over her head.

items.synopsis: China's infamous censors are methodical about keeping the country's closed internet free from information that the ruling Communist Party does not want its citizens seeing, but a new report from Human Rights Watch finds racist content on the Chinese internet targeting black people has become common.

title.children: Human Rights Watch calls on Beijing to remove racist content from Chinese internet

image.altText: A basketballer prepares to shoot a ball.

items.synopsis: Jock Landale will miss Australia's World Cup flight to Japan, as Jack White is called upon to take up a larger role.

title.children: Boomers star centre to miss flight to Japan ahead of World Cup after nasty ankle injury

image.altText: Two men shake hands after a football match.

items.synopsis: With crowds and viewership numbers breaking records all over the place, Australia looks to keep the momentum going by hosting the 2026 Women's Asian Cup.

title.children: As Australia looks to host the 2026 Women's Asian Cup, one country stands in the way of the party rolling on

items.synopsis: A light plane crashes into a street in Malaysia's central Selangor state, killing eight people on board and two motorists on the ground.

title.children: Fireball erupts as light plane crashes onto Malaysian motorway, killing 10
